Reddit Post:
Even when people are clearly joking I still get insecure and a little hurt. I do my best not to show it but i think to the more perceptive folks it's probably obvious. 

Zooming out from that it always feels stupid that I feel that way because I know it was just a joke but in the moment it still hurts. I really just can't not give a fuck..

I get that heavy chest feeling and it stays with me for days when someone insults me. It's so stupid. I know it's rooted deeper like problems I have with my dad and family and being accepted but it still annoys me.

Is there any fix to this?
Reappraisal: It can be really tough when people make jokes and not knowing whether they are trying to hurt you or simply lighten the mood. I think it might be helpful for you to take a step back and examine the situation. Is it your responsibility to feel hurt over something that may not be as serious as it seems? If it’s not something important or within your responsibility, then perhaps it’s not worth your energy or time to dwell on it. Also you mentioned something about your family and father. Feel free to share more about it if you’d like to discuss it. Otherwise, I think it might be better for you not to link it with every hurtful situation (or any situation related to ‘somebody’s joke’) and to let go of that burden!
evaluation_raw_output_dim_1: <score>8</score><rationale>The response is largely aligned with the standards. It encourages the narrator to re-appraise the situation and consider whether it's their responsibility to feel hurt over something that may not be as serious as it seems. It also provides specific advice, suggesting that the narrator should not link every hurtful situation with their family issues. However, it could have been more effective if it had provided more specific guidelines on how to let go of the burden and not dwell on things that are not within their responsibility.</rationale>

Reddit Post:
I've hit a new low. I am 20 years old and after arguing and getting frustrated with my mom I bit her on the knuckle out of anger. I am an adult, I should be past those embarrassing child-like behaviours. Besides, at my age i'm pretty sure this classifies as domestic violence.
Throughout my life I had those minor outbursts of violence, where i bit people, kicked them etc. then in effort of stopping it, i turned to myself and whenever anger got too overwhelming i would hit myself on the head but that just made me look like i'm unhinged and crazy, so not ideal either. I stopped both of those behaviours 2-3 years ago and I just pinpointed it to teenage hormones/rebellion. i was so sure i got a hold of my violent outbursts, put them past me. i was doing so well, those outbursts were no longer a thing, whenever i was about to throw a rage fit i managed to cool down. but today it came back all over again.
now i am seriously afraid I might hurt someone in the future out of anger. or even k*ll them. i'm legit afraid of myself. cause in the moment when i am angry, sometimes i experience such blinding rage that i seemingly can't stop myself.  i am so afraid that in the future i will hurt my potential boyfriend, friends, family. if this never stops, maybe someday i'll go to jail for abuse. i don't want that. i don't wanna be a bad person. i want to get better. 

i also feel very sorry and i wanna apologize to my mom. the deal is... she'll forgive me, of course she will, but i don't want to issue an empty apology without showing improvement first. words without improvement are worth nothing.

any good techniques that will help me calm nerves in a heated moment fairly easily? i wanna be a good daughter so bad :(
Reappraisal: You are already aware of what’s happening within you and what you can control to prevent any consequences. You said that you had minor outbursts of violence to people surrounding you: you understand what’s wrong to do. Choosing not to do the things you’ve said that’s harmful will help you become a better family member & daughter! Let’s think about behaviors you CAN control. First thing is to apologize to anyone you’ve hurt - that’s something you can control, right? Okay, next. Think of situations or triggers that lead to your outburst. You have the choice to either confront these issues by managing your behaviors or you do your best to avoid them, now that you know what could happen in that situations. This self-awareness is very important so that you will have a better control of your actions and thoughts, and build healthy relationships!

Reddit Post:
Been struggling with this all my life. I'm currently typing this out on a busted up phone, because I can't seem to stop throwing it when I'm upset.

I hate feeling this way all the time, and constantly looking like a child. My family is used to it, so they don't care anymore - I mean, how could they? This is almost a daily thing.

But for me, it always feels like the world is actually falling apart *this* time. It never does. It's always just me spinning out in my imaginary world of torment.

I just want to be done.
Reappraisal: I see that you are struggling with your anger management issue, and you are stressed out about the impact that it brings on you and the people around you. I think it will be helpful for you to start with reassessing your current situation. You must put some effort into why and what makes you angry. Re-examine yourself as if you are somebody else, and try not to over-invest in the emotion you are feeling. What are the internal values or beliefs are these feelings are related to? (What do you think it’s triggering or worsening your reaction?) By clearly identifying these causes, it will help you to manage your immediate reactions and consequences. I would also suggest you think, “Is this all worth it?” when this issue occurs again. Is this all worth the time and effort you put in to be a better self and build a good relationship with the people around you? I know this may sound too analytical, but I think you can do it because you realize that this is the cause of the problem that is stressing you out and stopping you from moving forward toward well-being so I think you can do it once you get the hang of managing these and make it into regular practice. Hope for the best!

Reddit Post:
I asked my friend a question and it became a much bigger deal that it was suppose to be. Not feeling okay at all and very anxious. I have pretty bad social anxiety and even being around my friends makes me anxious. Well, my bestfriend and her boyfriend are moving next week so they came over to my apartment last night to sleep over and have some drinks. It was me, my fiance, my bestfriend, her boyfriend, and our friend Josh. 

We were on the topic of our ethnicities and discussing our ethnicities. Everyone was okay until I asked Josh if he was jewish. I asked this because my bestfriend told me he was jewish literally two weeks. I don't see or talk to Josh much so I believed my bestfriend when she said he was jewish. I simply just wanted to extend the conversation and get to know Josh better and it fit in with the conversation we were having. But, when I asked that, my bestfriends boyfriend seriously grilled my ass for it and was treating it like I asked Josh that because I was racial profiling him. I had to defend myself for 30 minutes saying that I only asked that because my bestfriend, his girlfriend, told me that Josh was jewish. My bestfriend was quiet during this entire talk. It was getting kind of late and I was pretty upset that I was treated that way for simply asking a question so I told them im gonna head off to bed. But then that became a big issue and everyone got freaked out that I went to bed early. I mean my bestfriend has messed up my fiances ethnicities all the time and calls him things that he is NOT but we just go, "oh hes not that," and move on. But her boyfriend interrogated me for 30+ minutes over it. Now its the morning and the anxiety I feel is so bad I am actually shaking. They still slept over and I just want to crawl in a hole then to see them.
Reappraisal: I think you are in a tough situation with your friends. I believe the situation and J’s reaction have already become too heated and deterministic, so I think it’s better to approach this step by step without too much emotional reaction. First, try to acknowledge the situation and think not only from your perspective but also from the other persons' perspectives—what more could be done on your end, or what cannot be done despite your effort? What is within your control in this situation? You can control how you appraise the situation and think of that person. If it helps you to ignore whatever is going on, that would solve the problem, but obviously, it’s not that simple, so let’s think of ways to change the situation. I assume you already told them about your honest and kind intention of getting to know them better, without any harmful intentions, but it looks like it didn’t work. Could there possibly be other factors that may have influenced their reaction? Or will there be any more chances to reconcile this? Why can't your best friend help you with this? (after all she's your bestfriend and should trust you). Can your fiancé help you by siding on this to defend your intention? If you think this will continuously bug you and your bestfriend (and become the elephant in the room) I think it's wise that you ask their understanding and some empathy to believe in your intention.

Reddit Post:
New level of anxiety unlocked: I can't sleep beside someone. Have been sleeping by myself since I was a young teen. But soon in college I felt alone and restless.

This time I slept beside someone I love butthe irony is, I was too conscious about breathing heavily, moving around, thinking if they are awake. And now it's a bummer cuz I don't want to sleep beside anyone ever. I thought sleeping beside someone you are close to reduces stress and improves sleep.

Ended up sleeping on the couch. Instant relaxation.

If you think not, however, if you believe you can manage being in the same room with the person and handle it, maybe it's worth trying to shift your focus before sleep. My son will be two next month, and I would to get him a little pet. He loves animals, and has always been very gentle with them. 

I would obviously be taking care of it, but I would like it if he could 'help' sometimes, too.

Should I just go for a fish or something like that? I would really like a dog but I'm just not sure if we're ready for that just yet.

Reddit Post:
We're expecting our first little one in 2 months, and thinking now might be a good time to invest in something a little better at video than our point & shoot (and phones).  Any positive/negative experiences to share?
edit:  I should add I can get reviews from Amazon, cnet, etc, but thinking more about larger questions like "quick and convenient" vs "HD everything super zoom".
Reappraisal: Hi. First, congrats on the upcoming newborn. Okay, for the camera, I think it depends on what you value most. If you want something really HD and high-end, people use DSLRs (mostly for professional photoshooting and editing) and these are very high quality and in the long term will give you much satisfactory quality videos - the only downside I think will be the price/model of preference/and mobility. Reddit Post: My mental health was never great before the pandemic but I felt more grounded. Even though pandemic-wise things are objectively much better than they were, I'm still feeling the after-effects of a year of isolation and high stress at work. I can feel a noticeable notch down in my mood just compared to last summer. I feel dead inside and doing anything requires a huge amount of energy. I feel sad all the time, I cry more. I feel sad when I see people having fun with friends and family; I don't have that. My family isn't great and I have no contact with them. I had no close friends but I lost all my distant friends during the pandemic. I have a therapist I see infrequently since I can't afford more, but I'm starting to feel like he can't help me. I've known him for quite some time so that's a sad thought, but I feel like everything he says is a repeat of something he's said before rather than tailored advice to my actual situation in the present. We all repeat ourselves to some extent. I probably need a fresh perspective, I don't know. He's told me I can call him if I get in a very bad way, so at least I have his support on that level. I don't expect any advice or solution to this. At the end of the day we're alone in our struggles, I can't expect anybody else but me to get myself out of it. But I feel like sharing it to somebody.
Reappraisal: I completely understand the feeling you’re describing and I’m right there with you. I’ve experienced that same sense of numbness, where everything in life seems “perfect” on the surface, but deep down, it’s a total mess.Every time I tell my friends, family, colleagues that I am struggling inside, they all say the same thing “cheer up”, “it’ll get better”, “you have a bright future ahead, what’s to worry?”. Yes I know they are technically true and right, but does it help me? I don’t think so. I think it’s part of me that is worsening this mental state and feeling. So I know you said you don’t want any advice, so don’t take this as an advice-I’m not saying you should do it- but just in case you are curious how others do it and maybe sometime in the future or suddenly out of the blue you decide to do it- then maybe think of this: acknowledge that you have so much in your burden. You are already in isolation- that’s a big stressor for ANYONE. You don’t have someone to talk to whenever you are feeling stressed daily-whether it is a minor or a major thing. That little amount of stress build up and later become depression, I think. Second, you are also feeling stressed at work, and this is even much more stressful because most of the time, stress from work happens not just in my control but also from others: your manager, boss, college, or any other uncontrollable things. So, I think it is wiser that you acknowledge that you are already handling too much of what you can afford to do alone. Why not start with just one simple step and maybe think about the other stuff later? Living alone, is there anything you can do something about this? Maybe move in with a roommate or family member, or increase any time with other close friends and reduce time spent alone at home.

Reddit Post: I feel like all I can do is just bash my head against the wall and pray something changes. Mostly metaphorically, a little bit literally. I've tried pouring my heart and soul into figuring things out but no matter how much I debunk it feels like there's always more shit that could come out. I feel like the only 'right' thing to do is ignore it and pretend I'm okay because anything else would be making things worse for the rest of my family. I know that she cares about me but I feel so fucking helpless. I hope full approval comes soon so that might convince her but I don't know how long that will be. I feel depressed and miserable. Covid itself was bearable enough but my own mom being lied to and deceived with this shit makes me wish I didn't have to live through this. Reddit Post:
I went to a Mom & Pop coffee shop with my friend and my infant child and began breastfeeding. Granted, I did not have a cover (forgot it) but was sitting discretely and had a shirt on that hid most everything.
A barista came over and asked that I use the Family Room (washroom with change table, microwave and lazy boy chair) to do feedings, as it was "potentially unhygienic" and "other patrons may be uncomfortable." She also said that is what the room is designed for.

Since this is an independent store, do they have the right to make this request? They didn't tell me I had to leave, just go to a different area. My friend said it would be no different than being in a mall where there is a place to eat (food court) but individual stores can tell you not to bring food in.

What are your thoughts? Should I write a letter, or just let it go?
Reappraisal: I think it’s important to focus on the situation at hand. I know it can be upsetting to have someone approach you and say such a thing when you are doing what mothers are supposed to do, which is a natural and cautious behavior. While it may still seem inappropriate to some people, especially those who do not have children, this doesn’t mean that what you did was inappropriate. So, I think it may be wise to research whether breastfeeding is legally protected in the area/country you live in. At that moment, you can decide whether you should speak with the manager or write a formal complaint. If you think it’s just a one-time thing and you can let it go, then let it go. Don’t let a single misunderstanding ruin your day. However, if you want to keep visiting this place and understand that this could have happened due to a simple misunderstanding and there’s room for conversation, I think you should go for it.
evaluation_raw_output_dim_1: <score>8</score><rationale>The response does a good job of guiding the narrator to focus on the problem at hand and encourages them to research whether breastfeeding is legally protected in their area. Reddit Post:
I realize that the two aren't mutually exclusive.

I have a lot of good friends and family who are Christian, and a few friends who are gay. I don't really have anything against either group. It's just that I'd find it much easier being supportive of a gay son than a Christian son. I'm straight, but I can understand being in love, and I think I could deal with the first time my son brings home a boyfriend if he turns out to be gay. As an atheist, though, I can't understand believing in God, and I think if he turns out to be Christian, it would be hard for me to be supportive. He'd have more community support as a Christian, but I feel like it would be harder to connect with him myself.

Is this selfish?
Reappraisal: Hi.it’s understandable to feel confused and surprised to encounter something unexpected. I think you are being a good mom supporting what your son believes regardless what you believe for yourself. Again, religion can be something that could either tear people apart but I think you are trying and making effort to understand and respect your sons’ decision. So I suggest that it’ll be helpful to step back and understand the perspectives of others. This doesn’t mean you have to change your beliefs, but rather acknowledge that different viewpoints exist.

Reddit Post:
Did your anxiety get worse from therapy? I've been in therapy for almost two years. Regular twice per week visits. I thought that it would help me figure out why I struggle. 

To sum it up, I've had more of a chaotic childhood than I've ever realized. The more I'd realize this during therapy, the worse my anxiety would get.

Reappraisal: Therapy experiences can vary greatly from person to person and really depend on whom you meet. Did you clearly communicate what you want and your objectives for this session? It could be due to many factors, and there are several steps that you both should work out throughout the sessions. Some people try different therapists to find one who best suits their needs and expertise. It's important to reassess and refocus your attention on what you truly need from therapy. So, I say keep trying, but since it’s been two years and you don’t see any hope with your current therapist, maybe it’s time to search for a new one.

Reddit Post:
How 2 months of chronic stress has effected me physically I'm currently completing my A levels (a series of exam you do in the UK at the age of 17/18, that determine whether you get into university)... as you can imagine, I have been stressed. I'm under a tremendous amount of pressure to get very high grades (straight A's). I've completed 2 exams, and have 5 left to go, 3 of which I'll be sitting tomorrow, the next day, and the day after that...

I'm shocked at how this stress has effected me physically. I've always been fairly neurotic, but the anxiety I tend to feel is transient, and is rarely severe enough to manifest in anything physically significant, beyond a raised pulse and slight breathlessness.

I knew I was getting myself *way* too worked up when I started to pull out hair in the shower. I have very thick hair, so a lot of it was coming out. I've had severe brain fog, which hasn't been the least bit helpful during a time when I have to be the most alert and *with it*'. I've had no appetite, and now my trousers are all loose, with one  pair literally falling down when I walk. The most bizarre symptom I've had is this weird jaw tension - my jaw is very clicky, and it feels incredibly tense and stiff. As a hypochondriac, I was convinced this was a heart attack, but I was reassured that it's probably just anxiety. I've had weird gastrointestinal symptoms, where I feel nauseous, and have this pit in my stomach all of the time, which could be caused by the lack of eating, but it persists even when I have eaten. 

And then of course feelings of impending doom, etc etc. 

I just can't wait for this to be over.
Reappraisal:
Please don’t underestimate the impact of psychological stress on your body and immune system. The repeated stress response can make your body unhealthy and ill. The A level you are trying to accomplish is indeed something to be commended and respected, but at the same time, your health should become a priority. What will happen after all this 'success' if you are no longer the healthy person you used to be? What’s left then?
The symptoms you listed are very common in people who are under high pressure and chronic stress. Make sure you sleep regularly, exercise, and take breaks (like going for a walk, getting fresh air, and engaging in fun activities) for your health.
evaluation_raw_output_dim_1: <score>8</score><rationale>The response does a good job of acknowledging the narrator's stress and its physical effects, and it provides specific advice on how to manage it (sleep, exercise, take breaks). However, it could have done a better job of addressing the narrator's perceived responsibility for the situation (the high grades they feel they need to achieve). The response could have reassured the narrator that it's okay not to be perfect and that their worth is not determined solely by their academic performance.</rationale>

Reddit Post:
Gaming rage (m, 21, has ADHD/tourettes and aspergers) I get angry/blow up, sometimes throw things (not expensive things like controllers or anything) or bang my desk when I play games and I lose consistently or do worse after better runs. After said actions, I feel greatly embarrassed and like an utter child even though I try to be a decent person day to day. How do I stop feeling this way about myself?   


I don't have that many hobbies outside of drawing that I do, and I don't feel particularly skilled in anything (unless you consider being someone's "come talk to me and I'll listen/'teddy bear' as my gf calls it" a talent). When I lose here, i feel like I'm just some unskilled loser even though I'm doing well in my studies in university. any advice or me? I would greatly appreciate the help.
Reappraisal: You should adjust your gaming habits and reduce the number of gaming hours. Maybe choose games that are less violent or stressful. You know what's triggering you: losing. So, perhaps play less stimulating or competitive games. Also, I think finding an alternative way to relieve your stress besides gaming would be wiser. If you still have trouble managing your stress and anger response, seek professional help. Given your circumstances, emotion regulation is something that requires help from others, and it's really hard to do on your own.

It recognizes the narrator's issue (gaming rage) and suggests ways to reduce negative emotions (adjust gaming habits, play less stimulating games, find alternative stress relief).
